title: 6 Stunning Pictures Of Quasars and Black Holes Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
6 Stunning Pictures Of Quasars and Black Holes Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Jan 2, 2025 Source: Times Now

This article highlights six breathtaking images of quasars and black holes captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, showcasing the beauty and complexity of these astronomical phenomena.

  • Markarian 231: Two black holes in a close orbital dance illuminating the galaxy’s center.
  • Markarian 817: A spiral galaxy with blue star clusters surrounding an active supermassive black hole.
  • Quasar 3C 273: One of the closest quasars, its light took 2.5 billion years to reach Earth.
  • NGC 4438: A black hole exhibiting chaotic behavior with massive outflows of hot gas.
  • Quasar Tsunamis: Showcases the immense energy produced by quasars.
"Quasars produce immense energy, powered by a supermassive black hole consuming surrounding matter."

This collection of images not only illustrates the stunning visuals provided by the Hubble Space Telescope but also emphasizes the crucial role that these celestial bodies play in the universe.

title: Mars, Venus, Saturn and Jupiter to align the night sky in January: Here's the exact date and time - India TV News
summary:
January Planet Parade: Mars, Venus, Saturn, and Jupiter Align in the Night Sky

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: India TV News

This January, stargazers and astronomers will witness a spectacular alignment of four major planets: Mars, Venus, Saturn, and Jupiter, with the best view on January 17 and 18.

  • Mars will reach its brightest point on January 15-16, sitting prominently in the constellation Gemini.
  • Venus and Saturn will appear unusually close together, separated by only a few finger widths.
  • Jupiter will complete the planetary lineup, shining brightly in the sky.
  • Uranus and Neptune will also be visible for those with telescopes.
  • This event is referred to as a 'planet parade' by astronomers, highlighting its rarity and significance.
Mars’ opposition not only offers a visual delight but also provides ideal conditions for spacecraft launches and interplanetary missions.

This alignment not only captivates observers but also holds potential significance for future space exploration endeavors.

title: 2025's first meteor shower 'Quadrantid' to light up the skies: How to watch in India? - DNA India
summary:
2025's first meteor shower 'Quadrantid' to light up the skies: How to watch in India?

Publication Date: January 2, 2025 | Source: DNA India

The Quadrantid meteor shower, one of the most exciting astronomical events of 2025, will light up the night sky on 3 and 4 January. Active since 27 December, it promises a spectacular start to the New Year with meteors visible across the sky.

  • The Quadrantids have a brief peak, lasting only a few hours.
  • During the peak, you could see between 60 to 200 meteors per hour, depending on weather conditions, according to NASA.
  • This meteor shower originates from the asteroid 2003 EH1.
  • The best viewing times in India will be during the early hours of January 3 and 4.
  • Expected rates of meteors during the peak are between 80 to 120 per hour.
“To make the experience even better, the planetarium will set up telescopes for public viewing.” - Sumit Srivastava, senior scientific officer at the Indira Gandhi Planetarium

This meteor shower is a thrilling way to start 2025, offering a beautiful display for night sky watchers in India.
newTitle: How to Watch the Quadrantid Meteor Shower in India on January 3-4, 2025

title: 5 top space exploration milestones of 2024 - Hindustan Times

5 Top Space Exploration Milestones of 2024

Publication Date: January 2, 2025, Source: Hindustan Times

The year 2024 saw amazing milestones in space exploration, from groundbreaking discoveries to historic spacewalks.

  • NASA's Perseverance rover made significant discoveries on Mars, including organic molecules.
  • SpaceX's Polaris Dawn mission marked the first spacewalk conducted by civilians.
  • India successfully launched its small satellite, EOS-5, with the SSLV.
  • NASA's Parker Solar Probe made the closest dive to the sun, setting a new record.
  • Overall, 2024 was a landmark year with milestones shaping the future of space exploration.
“This discovery reignited discussions about the possibility of extraterrestrial life on Mars and beyond.”

2024 was a transformative year for space exploration, with innovations and findings reshaping our understanding of the cosmos.

Transforming the Moon Into Humanity’s First Space Hub - WIRED
summary:
Transforming the Moon Into Humanity’s First Space Hub

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Wired

This year marks a turning point in humanity’s relationship with the moon, as we begin to lay the foundations for a permanent presence on its surface, paving the way for our natural satellite to become an industrial hub.

  • Three critical elements for developing a lunar economy: access, refueling capabilities, and profitable enterprises.
  • SpaceX's Starship, designed for reuse and capable of delivering significant payloads to the moon, will demonstrate its capabilities in 2025.
  • Blue Origin’s Blue Moon lander will mark its maiden flight in 2025, crucial for establishing lunar infrastructure.
  • Nasa’s Artemis II mission intends to carry a crew around the moon in late 2025, a significant step towards lunar exploration.
  • The Lunar Gateway will be launched in 2025, acting as a logistics hub for lunar missions.
  • Starpath is developing a lunar gas station to support sustainable fuel production for return journeys to Earth.
“As these technologies take off, the moon will no longer be just a distant, desolate place. It will become the gateway to humanity’s future in space.”

This initiative paints an optimistic picture of the moon’s potential, transforming it into a stepping stone for future space exploration.
newTitle: Transforming the Moon Into Humanity’s First Space Hub

title: Space-Comm Expo reveals 2025 space industry trends and challenges - BroadcastProME.com
First meteor shower of 2025 is coming. How to catch the Quadrantids - India Today
summary:
First Meteor Shower of 2025: How to Catch the Quadrantids

Published On: Jan 2, 2025 | Source: India Today

As the new year unfolds, stargazers are in for a treat with the Quadrantid meteor shower, which peaks on January 3-4, 2025. This celestial event marks the first significant meteor shower of the year, offering a dazzling display of fireballs streaking across the night sky.

  • The Quadrantids are a unique meteor shower, originating from the asteroid 2003 EH1.
  • They peak at 60 to 120 meteors per hour under ideal conditions.
  • The meteor shower is visible particularly between 3:00 AM and 5:00 AM local time.
  • Quadrantids typically do not leave long trails but can be bright fireballs.
  • The meteor shower will remain active until January 16, 2025.
Nasa's William Cooke notes that while Quadrantids typically do not leave long trails, their heads can appear as bright fireballs.

Finding a dark location away from city lights is essential for optimal viewing. Minimal moonlight interference offers an excellent opportunity for celestial enthusiasts to enjoy this spectacular event.
newTitle: First Meteor Shower of 2025: How to Catch the Quadrantids

The article illustrates the unpredictable nature of space exploration, reminding us of the humor and humanity behind our attempts to conquer the final frontier.

Four Lunar and Solar eclipses in 2025: Check dates, timings and visibility in Odisha - OTV News
summary:
Four Lunar and Solar Eclipses in 2025: Dates, Timings, and Visibility in Odisha

Publication Date: Not specified Source: OTV News

The year 2025 will feature four major eclipses, including two partial solar and two total lunar eclipses. Among these, only one total lunar eclipse will be visible from India.

  • The first total lunar eclipse is on March 14, not visible in India.
  • The first partial solar eclipse occurs on March 29, also not visible in India.
  • The notable lunar eclipse on September 7 will be fully observable from India, appearing blood-red.
  • The final partial solar eclipse will occur from September 21 to 22, not visible from India, focusing on Australia and Antarctica.
“The lunar eclipse on September 7 and 8 will be visible in India. It can be witnessed with the naked eye and will last for a long period, being visible until 12:22 AM.” - Suvendu Pattnaik

The upcoming eclipses present a unique opportunity for Indian observers, especially the September lunar eclipse, which promises a spectacular view.

title: DNE reviews 10 groundbreaking scientific discoveries of 2024 - Daily News Egypt
NASA probe safely completes closest-ever approach to Sun - Kashmir Reader
summary:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest Approach to Sun

Date: 2022-12-30, Source: NASA

On December 24, NASA’s Parker Solar Probe successfully completed the closest-ever approach to the Sun, reaching a distance of 3.8 million miles (6.1 million kilometers) from the Sun's surface. The probe, traveling at speeds up to 430,000 mph (692,000 kph), endured temperatures up to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit (982 degrees Celsius) in the Sun’s outer atmosphere, the corona.

  1. The Parker Solar Probe, launched in 2018, aims to study the Sun and help scientists understand why the Sun's outer atmosphere is hundreds of times hotter than its surface.
  2. The spacecraft uses gravity-assist flybys of Venus to inch closer to the Sun with each orbit.
  3. Data from the probe might help answer what drives the solar wind and better understand solar energetic particles.
“This mission allows us to get closer to the Sun than ever before, helping scientists understand how the solar wind forms, why the Sun’s outer layer heats up to millions of degrees, and how energetic particles accelerate near light speed.” - NASA

The Parker Solar Probe is expected to send detailed telemetry data about its latest journey on January 1.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest Approach to Sun

The Future of Space Exploration: Robots vs. Humans

Date & Source: December 31, 2024. Source: TechSpot

Introduction: As robotic spacecraft achieve remarkable feats in extreme environments, scientists debate the future role of human astronauts in space exploration.

  • Robotic missions are cheaper than human spaceflight.
  • Advancements in AI could make robots more capable than humans in space.
  • Human-led missions provide national prestige and enable certain scientific research.
  • Some advocate for a balanced approach, combining human and robotic missions.
Lord Martin Rees, UK's Astronomer Royal: "Rapid advancements in robotics are reducing the need to send humans into space using 'taxpayer's money.'"

Conclusion: The future of space exploration may lie in a balance between human and robotic missions, each with its unique advantages and capabilities.

Kessler Syndrome could disrupt communications by knocking out Wi-Fi and mobile phones due to increasing space junk.

  • Recent increases in space debris have raised alarms among experts.

  • Over 130 million pieces of space junk are currently orbiting Earth, with thousands of potential collision risks every day.

The ongoing proliferation of space debris necessitates urgent intervention to mitigate potentially catastrophic risks to global communication systems.

title: How Artemis will land humans on the Moon - Astronomy Magazine
summary:
Artemis: NASA's Plan to Return Humans to the Moon

Date: 2024-12-15, Source: Astronomy Magazine

The Artemis program aims to return humans to the Moon by the end of the decade, marking the first time since the Apollo era. This article explores the history, key aspects, and challenges of the Artemis program, along with notable spacecraft and rockets involved.

History and Background

Sixty-five years ago, the USSR launched Luna 2, the first robotic mission to reach the Moon. The U.S. responded with the Apollo program, which resulted in the first human Moon landing. After a pause in lunar exploration, NASA is now working with international partners to resume human exploration of the Moon through the Artemis program.

Artemis Plan and Missions

  • Artemis 1: Uncrewed test flight of the Space Launch System (SLS) and Orion spacecraft, launched in 2022.
  • Artemis 2: Crewed mission to orbit the Moon using the SLS and Orion, tentatively scheduled for 2025.
  • Artemis 3: First crewed lunar landing since Apollo, using SpaceX's Starship HLS, planned for 2026 or later.
  • Artemis 4: Establishment of the Lunar Gateway space station, planned for 2028 or later.
  • Artemis 5: First use of Blue Origin's Blue Moon lander, planned for 2030 or later.

Challenges and Delays

The Artemis program faces technical challenges and delays, including issues with the Orion heat shield, spacesuit development, and the underperformance of SpaceX's Super Heavy rocket.

Notable Quotes

"As long as there is a national will to return to the Moon hand-in-hand with international partners, these obstacles can be overcome and more human footprints will join those left on the Moon half a century ago by the heroes of the Apollo era."

Image Caption: The Starship HLS stands like a giant 1950s science-fiction spaceship in this artist’s concept, spanning 30 feet (9 m) wide and reaching 160 feet (50 m) above the Moon’s surface. Credit: NASA
newTitle: Artemis: NASA's Plan to Return Humans to the Moon
